story:
Alle Informationen auf deutsch gibt es auf unserer Homepage: http://bosolarcar.de/crowdfunding/

 

The SolarBuggy project

We are a team of students at Bochum University of Applied Sciences who strive to engineer a buggy which is capable of driving across a sand desert powered by solar energy only. We have already converted a regular buggy into a SolarBuggy called “Open World” and driven across Tanami Road in Australia in 2015, now we dream bigger and better! 

At our university interdisciplinary projects concerning SolarCars have a history of 18 years. We strive to make this world a better one, building vehicles that rely on the sun instead of fuel. In doing so, we show the potential of solar energy, particularly the use of portable energy. This makes it viable for everyone on this planet and it is getting more viable all the time, as cells get better as well. This campaign is aimed at the heart of this project. We need huge solar arrays, because without them, our extraordinary and pioneering project won't be as extraordinary anymore.

We are planning to build a SolarBuggy every two years in order to get better and better. Currently, we are working on the 2nd project "Froggee", engineering a buggy, with which we plan to drive across the Simpson Desert in Australia and set a new Guinness World Record. 

This record is for the fastest time to cross the Simpson Desert by solar-powered land vehicle, following the french line.

We have already started working on the 3rd cycle buggy, provisional title PHOENIX. We constantly profit from the experience and knowledge already gained from "Open World".

So what exactly is a SolarBuggy? 

First of all, it does not have a combustion engine but electrical motors instead. What makes it solar is that these motors are powered by solar cells which enable this Buggy to drive without stopping at a charging station. We don't produce any exhaust and therefore don't put a strain on the environment. We can simply stop and charge wherever we are by unfolding our solar array. This energy is of course stored in batteries, so clouds, tunnels and the like pose no problems. We also have cells on the roof to extend our range and hence the time we can drive. 


SolarBuggy "Open World" in Monaco at Formula E, on Texel and at a quarry

For both of our upcoming projects, 2nd and 3rd cycle, we need solar arrays. We are planning to build one set, which can be used for both buggies as the modules are not fixed, but interchangeable.

As they are one of the most costly aspects of building a SolarBuggy, this campaign is aimed at financing those arrays. So in turn you are not just helping to realise one project, but keeping it going and realising two projects. 

What you have seen and heard in the video above is of course, as we are developing the project, not final and things can still change. We have, for example, managed to reduce our array size from 30sqm to almost 25 sqm.

Our solar array

Foldable solar modules

To understand what you are financing, here’s an explanation of what a solar array is and how we plan to implement ours. 

To reach our goal of being able to charge our batteries in the desert in 3 hours, we will need approximately 25 sqm of solar cells. This means that we will build two big modules which are foldable and therefore fit inside the buggy. We also have about 2-2.5 sqm of panels on the roof to extend our range. 

The solar roof will be fixed on each buggy, but the big array can be reused. Our plan is to design a resistant array for the 2nd cycle "Froggee", take them to Australia and then use them again in the 3rd cycle for PHOENIX. 

An array consists of solar cells which are connected to strings (or panels), and those are then again connected to form a module. These modules form the array.

This means that in the first step, the cells are soldered to strings, then these strings have to be laminated in several steps. Furthermore, we need to interconnect these strings and implement them in the foldable construction to complete the array. This is quite a costly undertaking, so we are hoping for your support.

Here you can see how a module will be folded for transport

SolarBuggy "Froggee"

SolarBuggy " Froggee" on a little test run at the workshop

In this 2nd cycle "Froggee" we are working closely with Eric Vigouroux (Eric Vigouroux Racing- EVR), whom you might know from the Dakar Rally. He came into contact with us through Auktora, a company founded by former members of the SolarCar that still works closely together with us.

We wanted to give him a chance to introduce himself and tell his view on our project:

Eric Vigouroux

"As you know, I’m a former professional rally-raid driver. I’ve been doing off-road racing for almost 20 years across the most beautiful deserts in the world, but always with petrol powered race cars. I love racing, but I love nature even better, this is why, at the age of 50, I’ve decided to stop my carreer as a rally driver to start a new challenge: designing and building a clean off-road electric vehicle. My dream is to one day be able to go back in the desert with a totally different approach and maybe invent a new way ofracing, where speed won’t be the main goal. Being able to go further by managing energy resources, doing a good navigation, having a good strategy, reading the terrain so the vehicle can progress with less energy is the way for me to do off-road competition in the future.

After I did a lot of research on the internet, I discovered some very interesting articles about Bochum University of Applied Sciences’ achievements in the field of solar electric vehicles. This is why I met with Auktora in October 2014, I wanted to share my vision with the solar team and see if they were willing to work with me in order to make dream happened. 2 years later, Froggee was born. It is actually the lightest and the most performing off-road electric buggy in the world. When the students of Bochum University of Applied Sciences contacted me with the idea to turn my EVR buggy into a solar vehicle with the goal to set a new record in the desert of Simpson in Australia, I said yes immediately (and not only because we will follow the French line). This is exactly what I want to do for the upcoming year, use my off-road skills to promote sustainable energy and electromobility by taking part take part in this kind of challenges. Having a chance to work with young engineers who will design and build tomorrow’s vehicles is a great opportunity for me. I’m very happy to bring my experience in this project and, together with the students, show the world that today we can go pretty much anywhere with an off-road buggy, only using sustainable energy. I also like the idea of proving to myself that it’s never too late to change for better."

While this Buggy is already electrical, neither is it yet fit for a desert, nor was it supposed to be street legal, which it will have to be for our purpose.

So there is still a lot to be done on the mechanics and the electrics. And of course the solar array is also still missing, which we hope you can help us with! 

The new SolarBuggy PHOENIX

The first design steps

At the same time as working on the new SolarBuggy, we have already started developing the SolarBuggy PHOENIX (3rd generation). Project PHOENIX’s main aim is to build a vehicle that is perfectly suited to the conditions in an off-road environment. This also means that we build this vehicle from scratch, as the modification of a vehicle always means having to compromise. 

As conception and development of a new vehicle take a lot of time, we decided to start work early and lay the cornerstone for this ambitious project. 

It is going to have all-wheel drive, powered via two electrical motors, one for each axle. 

For an optimal distribution of weight, the traction battery will be located in the centre of the vehicle. The batteries will be fully charged within three hours via the solar generator. 

To be able to easily manoeuver through difficult terrain and even sand dunes, chassis clearance will be 350mm and motor capacity will be 226 kW peak.

Your help is crucial

For the realisation of the project, solar cells are crucial to power the buggy with clean, sustainable energy. This makes the vehicles independent from charging stations and, being an off-roader, also independent from infrastructure in general, therefore leading the way to an autonomous and clean future. 

Not only do the SolarCar projects of Bochum University of Applied Sciences bring forth innovative ideas, but also help students to a practical and mostly self-governed education additional to their regular courses. Here, skills, teamworking abilities and experience are gained which could never be learned in an auditorium.

With your support, we want to make this world a greener one!

Charging the SolarBuggy in Darwin, Australia

Our history

Solar electromobility at Bochum University of Applied Sciences can look back at several years of experience. We started off building SolarCars, which are road cars powered by solar energy. 

In late 2012 the SolarBuggy project, originating from beforehand mentioned SolarCar project, was initialized by the donation of a usual buggy. The SolarBuggy project is being led by a management comprised of students. The students of the team are from different majors like electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, mechatronics and engineering management. 

In August 2015, the first SolarBuggy "Open World" was shipped to Australia. In November 2015 the team successfully travelled across an 829 km-track through the Tanami Desert in 8 days. They challenged sand and dust only with the help of solar energy. It is the first solar based vehicle worldwide that accomplished an off-road track like that.

We are also regularly at events like the European Solar Challenge in Belgium.

Our "old" SolarBuggy on Tanami Road in Australia

Who we are

We are a team of 25 students from different disciplines, such as electrical engineering, mechatronics, engineering management, facilities engineering management, electromobility and mechanical engineering in bachelor and masters courses.

 

Project management  

    

      Marc Blüge                 Sebastian Efkes  

Marc is a postgraduate in electromobility and Sebastian in mechatronics. They are part of the team since 2013 and are still actively working on the buggy, as well as managing the project.  

Team lead 

Thies Fritzenkötter         Marius Tropper          Birgit Reuter  

     Mechanics                  Electronics                Media/PR  

Thies and Marius were also part of the first team. Thies is additionally working on the motor, Marius and Birgit also form the team working on the Solar Array.  Thies is a postgraduate in mechatronics, Marius in electromobility and Birgit is an undergraduate in electrical engineering.

Electric team

  • Battery

Patrick Schürmeyer       Timo Franke           Sascha Gisselmann  

This team is studying electrical engineering and is developing the battery block and Battery Management System for project PHOENIX and implements it. They also make the vehicle street legal.  

  • Motorcontroller

Christopher Schäfer      Chris Schitke

They’re postgraduates in electrical engineering and are in charge of the motorcontrollers and help out wherever they are needed in the electrical team.  

  • Electric contactors

Vishali Ravichandran  

She is an Indian exchange student, studying electrical engineering, who is in charge of relaying the electric contactors.  

  • Controlling

   

      Tristan Gall  

He is studying electrical engineering and is currently doing the controlling.  

  • Test runs

  Johanna Meyer  

She is studying technical management energy, building services and environmental engineering in Munster and is in charge of organising test runs for the new buggy.  

  • Low-voltage system

   

       Jan Spieker                 Gerrit Rothstein  

They are undergraduates, Jan is studying mechatronics, Gerrit electrical engineering, who are developing and implementing the low-voltage system.

Mechanic team

  • Cooling system

 

    Oliver Boczek 

He is a postgraduate in mechanical engineering. His discipline is the cooling system for the buggy.  

  • Design

 Maximilian Ewert        Moritz Roggentin 

Both of them are studying industrial design at Folkwang University of the Arts and form the design team.  

  • Design engineering  

       

   Christian                        Alexander                            Ian                               Marcel                         Parreidt                        Wallersheim                  Pfizenmaier-                   Wiese                                                                                                              Boxleitner

They are the design engineering team and all undergraduates except for Marcel, who is a postgraduate. Christian engineers the a-arms, Ian the shock absorbers, Marcel the axles and Alexander the solar array. Christian and Ian are studying Mechatronics, while Alexander and Marcel are studying Mechanical Engineering.  

  • Organisation  

 

Christopher Bonk  

He is a postgraduate in civil engineering at Duisburg-Essen University and organises our trip to Australia.

Program management

Matthias Wiemers                 Jan Hintz

Matthias is one of the founders of Auktora and deeply involved in all of the SolarCar projects of Bochum University of applied Sciences since 2006. He is functioning as program manager for both the SolarCar and the SolarBuggy. Jan has been part of the SolarCar since 2010, and is now also program manager of the buggy.

Please help us to finish this project, so we can go to Australia and show our brand-new buggies all the koalas, kangaroos and wallabies!

 

Also visit us on Facebook and our Website!

https://facebook.com/SolarBuggyHSBochum/

http://bosolarcar.de/solarbuggy/

For further information and more info on the rewards please check our FAQ!

Risks and challenges

We know our project is an ambitious one. Which is why we rely so much on your support. With this project we hope to show the world that solar mobility is not just a crazy idea, but it can actually power a vehicle, which can reach even the most remote places.
We also know that delays in production and shipment can pose a risk, but we're working on it every day, because we really want to make it.
We know we can do it, because we have already done it once before!

 

FAQ

 

What happens with my donation and how will it be handled?

Your contribution will be used for materials and parts for the buggy only.

How else can I support the project?

We will be happy if you tell your family and friends about the project. Additionally, you can share our page on facebook, like and share our youtube videos and spread the word.

Why do we have a flexible crowdfunding goal?

We aim for 10000€ to be able to build the heart of our buggy, the solar array. Further, we have many other costs in our project and the solar array is just one part of the buggy. That’s why we need any support we can get!

What do I get for my money and how do I profit from my investment?

Rewards:

Of course we only list your name as a supporter on our website if you agree.

Perk €1 or more

Solar Tourist

Thanks for your contribution!

Includes:

Thanks for your contribution!

Thanks for your contribution!
Be ready to move in with us on our website, roomie. You are now an official supporter.

We're as enthusiastic as you are! Thanks a lot.

  • High resolution pictures of the SolarBuggy

We consider you almost part of the team and a close partner. This is why we would like you to be at our rollout so you can meet the whole team and also drive the buggy you helped us build.

story_txt:
Alle Informationen auf deutsch gibt es auf unserer Homepage: http://bosolarcar.de/crowdfunding/
 The SolarBuggy projectWe are a team of students at Bochum University of Applied Sciences who strive to engineer a buggy which is capable of driving across a sand desert powered by solar energy only. We have already converted a regular buggy into a SolarBuggy called “Open World” and driven across Tanami Road in Australia in 2015, now we dream bigger and better! At our university interdisciplinary projects concerning SolarCars have a history of 18 years. We strive to make this world a better one, building vehicles that rely on the sun instead of fuel. In doing so, we show the potential of solar energy, particularly the use of portable energy. This makes it viable for everyone on this planet and it is getting more viable all the time, as cells get better as well. This campaign is aimed at the heart of this project. We need huge solar arrays, because without them, our extraordinary and pioneering project won't be as extraordinary anymore.We are planning to build a SolarBuggy every two years in order to get better and better. Currently, we are working on the 2nd project "Froggee", engineering a buggy, with which we plan to drive across the Simpson Desert in Australia and set a new Guinness World Record. This record is for the fastest time to cross the Simpson Desert by solar-powered land vehicle, following the french line.We have already started working on the 3rd cycle buggy, provisional title PHOENIX. We constantly profit from the experience and knowledge already gained from "Open World".So what exactly is a SolarBuggy? First of all, it does not have a combustion engine but electrical motors instead. What makes it solar is that these motors are powered by solar cells which enable this Buggy to drive without stopping at a charging station. We don't produce any exhaust and therefore don't put a strain on the environment. We can simply stop and charge wherever we are by unfolding our solar array. This energy is of course stored in batteries, so clouds, tunnels and the like pose no problems. We also have cells on the roof to extend our range and hence the time we can drive. SolarBuggy "Open World" in Monaco at Formula E, on Texel and at a quarryFor both of our upcoming projects, 2nd and 3rd cycle, we need solar arrays. We are planning to build one set, which can be used for both buggies as the modules are not fixed, but interchangeable.As they are one of the most costly aspects of building a SolarBuggy, this campaign is aimed at financing those arrays. So in turn you are not just helping to realise one project, but keeping it going and realising two projects. What you have seen and heard in the video above is of course, as we are developing the project, not final and things can still change. We have, for example, managed to reduce our array size from 30sqm to almost 25 sqm.Our solar arrayFoldable solar modulesTo understand what you are financing, here’s an explanation of what a solar array is and how we plan to implement ours. To reach our goal of being able to charge our batteries in the desert in 3 hours, we will need approximately 25 sqm of solar cells. This means that we will build two big modules which are foldable and therefore fit inside the buggy. We also have about 2-2.5 sqm of panels on the roof to extend our range. The solar roof will be fixed on each buggy, but the big array can be reused. Our plan is to design a resistant array for the 2nd cycle "Froggee", take them to Australia and then use them again in the 3rd cycle for PHOENIX. An array consists of solar cells which are connected to strings (or panels), and those are then again connected to form a module. These modules form the array.This means that in the first step, the cells are soldered to strings, then these strings have to be laminated in several steps. Furthermore, we need to interconnect these strings and implement them in the foldable construction to complete the array. This is quite a costly undertaking, so we are hoping for your support.Here you can see how a module will be folded for transportSolarBuggy "Froggee"SolarBuggy " Froggee" on a little test run at the workshopIn this 2nd cycle "Froggee" we are working closely with Eric Vigouroux (Eric Vigouroux Racing- EVR), whom you might know from the Dakar Rally. He came into contact with us through Auktora, a company founded by former members of the SolarCar that still works closely together with us.We wanted to give him a chance to introduce himself and tell his view on our project:Eric Vigouroux"As you know, I’m a former professional rally-raid driver. I’ve been doing off-road racing for almost 20 years across the most beautiful deserts in the world, but always with petrol powered race cars. I love racing, but I love nature even better, this is why, at the age of 50, I’ve decided to stop my carreer as a rally driver to start a new challenge: designing and building a clean off-road electric vehicle. My dream is to one day be able to go back in the desert with a totally different approach and maybe invent a new way ofracing, where speed won’t be the main goal. Being able to go further by managing energy resources, doing a good navigation, having a good strategy, reading the terrain so the vehicle can progress with less energy is the way for me to do off-road competition in the future.After I did a lot of research on the internet, I discovered some very interesting articles about Bochum University of Applied Sciences’ achievements in the field of solar electric vehicles. This is why I met with Auktora in October 2014, I wanted to share my vision with the solar team and see if they were willing to work with me in order to make dream happened. 2 years later, Froggee was born. It is actually the lightest and the most performing off-road electric buggy in the world. When the students of Bochum University of Applied Sciences contacted me with the idea to turn my EVR buggy into a solar vehicle with the goal to set a new record in the desert of Simpson in Australia, I said yes immediately (and not only because we will follow the French line). This is exactly what I want to do for the upcoming year, use my off-road skills to promote sustainable energy and electromobility by taking part take part in this kind of challenges. Having a chance to work with young engineers who will design and build tomorrow’s vehicles is a great opportunity for me. I’m very happy to bring my experience in this project and, together with the students, show the world that today we can go pretty much anywhere with an off-road buggy, only using sustainable energy. I also like the idea of proving to myself that it’s never too late to change for better."While this Buggy is already electrical, neither is it yet fit for a desert, nor was it supposed to be street legal, which it will have to be for our purpose.So there is still a lot to be done on the mechanics and the electrics. And of course the solar array is also still missing, which we hope you can help us with! The new SolarBuggy PHOENIXThe first design stepsAt the same time as working on the new SolarBuggy, we have already started developing the SolarBuggy PHOENIX (3rd generation). Project PHOENIX’s main aim is to build a vehicle that is perfectly suited to the conditions in an off-road environment. This also means that we build this vehicle from scratch, as the modification of a vehicle always means having to compromise. As conception and development of a new vehicle take a lot of time, we decided to start work early and lay the cornerstone for this ambitious project. It is going to have all-wheel drive, powered via two electrical motors, one for each axle. For an optimal distribution of weight, the traction battery will be located in the centre of the vehicle. The batteries will be fully charged within three hours via the solar generator. To be able to easily manoeuver through difficult terrain and even sand dunes, chassis clearance will be 350mm and motor capacity will be 226 kW peak.Your help is crucialFor the realisation of the project, solar cells are crucial to power the buggy with clean, sustainable energy. This makes the vehicles independent from charging stations and, being an off-roader, also independent from infrastructure in general, therefore leading the way to an autonomous and clean future. Not only do the SolarCar projects of Bochum University of Applied Sciences bring forth innovative ideas, but also help students to a practical and mostly self-governed education additional to their regular courses. Here, skills, teamworking abilities and experience are gained which could never be learned in an auditorium.With your support, we want to make this world a greener one!Charging the SolarBuggy in Darwin, AustraliaOur historySolar electromobility at Bochum University of Applied Sciences can look back at several years of experience. We started off building SolarCars, which are road cars powered by solar energy. In late 2012 the SolarBuggy project, originating from beforehand mentioned SolarCar project, was initialized by the donation of a usual buggy. The SolarBuggy project is being led by a management comprised of students. The students of the team are from different majors like electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, mechatronics and engineering management. In August 2015, the first SolarBuggy "Open World" was shipped to Australia. In November 2015 the team successfully travelled across an 829 km-track through the Tanami Desert in 8 days. They challenged sand and dust only with the help of solar energy. It is the first solar based vehicle worldwide that accomplished an off-road track like that.We are also regularly at events like the European Solar Challenge in Belgium.Our "old" SolarBuggy on Tanami Road in AustraliaWho we areWe are a team of 25 students from different disciplines, such as electrical engineering, mechatronics, engineering management, facilities engineering management, electromobility and mechanical engineering in bachelor and masters courses. Project management             Marc Blüge                 Sebastian Efkes  Marc is a postgraduate in electromobility and Sebastian in mechatronics. They are part of the team since 2013 and are still actively working on the buggy, as well as managing the project.  Team lead Thies Fritzenkötter         Marius Tropper          Birgit Reuter       Mechanics                  Electronics                Media/PR  Thies and Marius were also part of the first team. Thies is additionally working on the motor, Marius and Birgit also form the team working on the Solar Array.  Thies is a postgraduate in mechatronics, Marius in electromobility and Birgit is an undergraduate in electrical engineering.Electric teamBatteryPatrick Schürmeyer       Timo Franke           Sascha Gisselmann  This team is studying electrical engineering and is developing the battery block and Battery Management System for project PHOENIX and implements it. They also make the vehicle street legal.  MotorcontrollerChristopher Schäfer      Chris SchitkeThey’re postgraduates in electrical engineering and are in charge of the motorcontrollers and help out wherever they are needed in the electrical team.  Electric contactorsVishali Ravichandran  She is an Indian exchange student, studying electrical engineering, who is in charge of relaying the electric contactors.  Controlling         Tristan Gall  He is studying electrical engineering and is currently doing the controlling.  Test runs  Johanna Meyer  She is studying technical management energy, building services and environmental engineering in Munster and is in charge of organising test runs for the new buggy.  Low-voltage system          Jan Spieker                 Gerrit Rothstein  They are undergraduates, Jan is studying mechatronics, Gerrit electrical engineering, who are developing and implementing the low-voltage system.Mechanic teamCooling system     Oliver Boczek He is a postgraduate in mechanical engineering. His discipline is the cooling system for the buggy.  Design Maximilian Ewert        Moritz Roggentin Both of them are studying industrial design at Folkwang University of the Arts and form the design team.  Design engineering            Christian                        Alexander                            Ian                               Marcel                         Parreidt                        Wallersheim                  Pfizenmaier-                   Wiese                                                                                                              BoxleitnerThey are the design engineering team and all undergraduates except for Marcel, who is a postgraduate. Christian engineers the a-arms, Ian the shock absorbers, Marcel the axles and Alexander the solar array. Christian and Ian are studying Mechatronics, while Alexander and Marcel are studying Mechanical Engineering.  Organisation   Christopher Bonk  He is a postgraduate in civil engineering at Duisburg-Essen University and organises our trip to Australia.Program managementMatthias Wiemers                 Jan HintzMatthias is one of the founders of Auktora and deeply involved in all of the SolarCar projects of Bochum University of applied Sciences since 2006. He is functioning as program manager for both the SolarCar and the SolarBuggy. Jan has been part of the SolarCar since 2010, and is now also program manager of the buggy.Please help us to finish this project, so we can go to Australia and show our brand-new buggies all the koalas, kangaroos and wallabies! Also visit us on Facebook and our Website!https://facebook.com/SolarBuggyHSBochum/http://bosolarcar.de/solarbuggy/For further information and more info on the rewards please check our FAQ!Risks and challengesWe know our project is an ambitious one. Which is why we rely so much on your support. With this project we hope to show the world that solar mobility is not just a crazy idea, but it can actually power a vehicle, which can reach even the most remote places.We also know that delays in production and shipment can pose a risk, but we're working on it every day, because we really want to make it.We know we can do it, because we have already done it once before! FAQ What happens with my donation and how will it be handled?Your contribution will be used for materials and parts for the buggy only.How else can I support the project?We will be happy if you tell your family and friends about the project. Additionally, you can share our page on facebook, like and share our youtube videos and spread the word.Why do we have a flexible crowdfunding goal?We aim for 10000€ to be able to build the heart of our buggy, the solar array. Further, we have many other costs in our project and the solar array is just one part of the buggy. That’s why we need any support we can get!What do I get for my money and how do I profit from my investment?Rewards:Of course we only list your name as a supporter on our website if you agree.

Other
    16*

*Shipping fees may vary and will be calculated at the time of shipping.

story:
About the Founder

John Krisch has over 25 years experience in logistics. 10+ years he's been focused on the moving industry and trends in personal shipping. NOWSHIP focus is on the only growth area of this multi billion dollar industry. A consumer trend needing service for smaller moves. In John's experience as a mover, the daily requests from customers wanting to move boxes in the USA or internationally where the most difficult and often left without a solution. He created NOWSHIP to solve this growing problem.

About NOWSHIP

 Launched in early 2016, NOWSHIP has bootstrapped its way into a successful proof of concept ready to scale. The company did something ingenious,  modeled after the changes in the travel industry, Sites like Expedia & Travelocity changed the travel industry. Much like these pioneering companies, NOWSHIP buys unused shipping space from the trusted carriers we see delivering to our homes and offices everyday. NOWSHIP is the only shipping company without assets. Like Uber is the largest cab company in the world and Airbnb is the largest provider of hospitality services for lodging short or long term -NOWSHIP will become the largest provider of personal shipping and moving services.

Campaign Summary: Affiliate Growth

Moving companies are the first to be called with requests to move boxes of personal effects but moving companies turn these customers away without a solution.

NOWSHIP is that solution and through our campaign to affiliate with more moving companies across the USA, we can bring our amazing door to door services to the consumer. Providing solutions and saving customers money. It's the first step for NOWSHIP to become the game changer in a very traditional industry. Everyone moves at least several times in the life.

Your support of this campaign will bring in more moving companies who will refer business to our company. Movers spend thousands monthly to attract customers only to turn this growing number of consumers away. With your help, this won't happen.

What We Need & What You Get

We are starting our initial affiliate growth project asking for $25,000 in support. This will allow us to get more affiliates and have them refer this business to us. We even pay the mover a small commission for every booking resulting in their referral. This funding will result in immediate action to support growth in sales and more outlets to resell our services. 

No matter how much is raised, your support will help us bring on more moving company affiliates and get us further along our ultimate goal of becoming the consumer's choice for small moving services. 

All contribution levels include emailed updates on our progress

$10 Email thank you from NOWSHIP
$25 a personal email thank you from the founder
$50 a personally signed thank you letter from the founder
$100 Letter+ NOWSHIP T-SHIRT 


$200 Letter  + NOWSHIP T-SHIRT + a 4 pack of NOWSHIP BOXES (US & UK only)
$300 Letter + NOWSHIP T-SHIRT + Shipping 1 NOWSHIP BOX in the continental USA 
$600 Letter + NOWSHIP T-SHIRT + Shipping 4 NOWSHIP BOXES in the continental USA 
$1000 Letter + NOWSHIP T-SHIRT+ Shipping of 10 NOWSHIP BOXES in the continental USA 

THE KUBOX

$2500 Letter + NOWSHIP T-SHIRT + 1 KUBOX shipping in the continental USA 
+ 10 NOWSHIP BOXES with domestic shipping
$2500+ The $2500 level + Published on our websites under the Admirals Cup of Contributors*

*Can be supporters name, family name, in the name of another, a company name or anonymous. 

1 Box 1 Tree: You Contribution & a Tree

Replacing trees to be enjoyed, to educate our next generation to be good stewards and reap the benefits of reforestation tree by tree.  All levels of contribution will result in a tree being planted by school children as part of our 1 Box 1 Tree Program

45 of the shipping boxes used by NOWSHIP US and 50 NOWSHIP UK boxes are created through one single tree (mixing new and recycled resources). While these rugged shipping boxes keep our customer's goods safe (we've had no claims of damages), as a company NOWSHIP has decided we can no longer just be a consumer of  resources and it's time to give back.

To be clear, we won't be replacing trees to be harvested, instead we'll be replacing trees to be enjoyed, to educate our next generation to be good stewards and reap the benefits of reforestation tree by tree.

Risks & Challenges

We have already put our resources into gaining 100+ moving company affiliates. There are thousands of moving companies in the USA alone.

Converting more moving companies into NOWSHIP affiliates we believe is more than achievable with support. The challenge is to gain maximum exposure and we believe that is best done through exhibiting during industry gatherings.

More exposure & interaction with movers will result in more affiliate signups through regional, national, and international industry conferences.

Other Ways You Can Help

We so appreciate even considering support of NOWSHIP. We know everyone isn't always in the position to help fund but we believe you can help by getting the word out about our great company. If you or someone you know might need assistance in moving? 

Come by and visit http://nowship.com or http://uk.nowship.com -we're here to help!

As you're on Indiegogo, sharing NOWSHIP most definitely helps NOWSHIP.

story:
Thank you for your interest in our project, we are very grateful to share this with the world.  This campaign is run by an international team collaborating within Richard's Architecture-Design (R A+D), an interdisciplinary architecture and design consultation firm.  We are creating this campaign to raise funds for the North American launch of R A+D 's  development of the MINILOOP in North America.  R A+D has been in operation for 10 years, working with private, commercial, and government sectors in countries around the world on the leading edge of eco-design.  R A+D leader and Principal, Richard Moreta has over 30 years of experience in innovative design and architecture. 


MINILOOP is an internationally awarded system, winning awards at the Moscow Urban Forum 2017, and the Well-Tech Smart Cities Awards in Milan, Italy in 2017.  


MINILOOP is  one of the newest products in the pipeline for development at R A+D, which brings great innovation, sustainability, and renewable energy to our cities worldwide.  MINILOOP is a Vertical Master Plan Transit System, originally designed by Professor and Architect Richard Moreta Castillo, R A+D's founder and owner. It is designed to be a free transit method for commuters, with the options of renting a bike or e-bike, as well as a platform for taxis and delivery services.  The revenue brought in through digital advertisements along MINILOOP will pay for its running and maintenance, as once built, MINILOOP is a completely self-sustaining system energetically with its own renewable energy supply.  Additionally, selling power back to the local grid is another one of MINILOOP's revenue streams, which are explained below. 
 


We have set a goal of $150,000 USD raised for this campaign, which means only 6,000 people have to donate $25 or more for us to reach our goal!  Anything raised in excess if our goal will be greatly appreciated, and utilized responsibly to fulfill our team goals and milestones, as well as provide perks for contributors. 


Having contributors support us through this crowdfunding campaign will allow for R A+D's developments in North America for MINILOOP, firstly in Silicon Valley and San Francisco Bay Area, as well as the Greater Denver Area. The MINILOOP prototype will be created in facilities in the Greater Denver Area, and will be open for showing first to municipalities, partners and investors, and then to the public. MINILOOP's prototype will be built through conventional and 3D printing construction, using sustainable building materials, making it immensely cost effective and very easy to mass produce quickly.   


 

We at R A+D are here to create innovations for the betterment of humanity and our environment.  Our team comes from all over the planet including the United States, Italy, Bangladesh, Singapore, Germany, Dominican Republic, and more.  Our United States Team will be spearheading and managing the first MINILOOP project and beginning the foundation of MINILOOP's own company, MINILOOP International, LLC.  We find that our diversity and global influence is a wonderful strength and advantage in our eco-design services to have the perspective of global collaboration.  We do this with the intention of catalyzing positive shifts and transforming our cities and communities which are long overdue for upgrades in infrastructure and technology.  At the same time, we provide sustainable and feasible solutions to be implemented to make our world better.   

 

The first MINILOOP has already been 100% approved for a 3 km circuit by the Mayor of Skolkovo, a suburb of Moscow known as the Silicon Valley equivalent of Russia. 

  

Statistics 
"In the U.S. alone, congestion cost $305 billion last year, an increase of $10 billion from 2016"
(CityLab Article on INRIX Traffic Study)


"In 2015, 5,376 pedestrians and 818 bicyclists were killed in crashes with motor vehicles" (National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, Traffic Safety Facts)​ 

 

"4.2 million deaths every year as a result of exposure to ambient (outdoor) air pollution"
(World Health Organization) 






MINILOOP transportation systems are built for the people, and are setting a new precedent in Smart Mobility which takes into consideration many aspects of public health, from air pollution to pedestrian/cyclist traffic deaths and injuries.  MINILOOP is being brought to different regions around the world by different names such as ECO-BAHN and BICIMETRO, MINILOOP being the name chosen for North America.  Construction methods such as 3D Printing are being considered for making the MINILOOP as cost effective, and an easily replicated system with modular building techniques.  

 

 

 

MINILOOP is one step in the right direction for urban development and public transit systems, allowing urban environments to be designed for the ease and well-being of its communities, and greater renewable energy resource distribution. 

 

 

 

 

MINILOOP's main source of revenue will be digital marketing ads on billboards along the inside and outside of the MINILOOP's length, as well as the other aforementioned revenue streams to ensure a timely ROI for investors. 

 

When MINILOOP was designed, we sought to change the way we perceive travel and commuting as an individual.   Cost effective freedom to travel as an individual, especially with zero-emissions transit systems, is a privilege each us deserve to experience.  Providing these means of safe, around the clock travel gives more incentive for bicycle, e-bike, and e-scooter travel, in turn taking more vehicles off the road and mitigating traffic and air pollution.  Because the cyclists are in their own interdependent routes they can sustain consistent high rates of speed and efficiency, while convention vehicle traffic can have its own pace at street level, creating even better traffic flow. 

 

 

From R A+D's inception of MINILOOP, public health and safety has been a key concern, and by implementing these MINILOOP platforms the amount of the incidents can be reduced. Too often do we hear of children and adults in pedestrian/bicycle incidents with automobiles.  As family members, partners and parents ourselves, our hearts go out to those families and communities around the world wounded by these kinds of tragedies.  

 

Year-round, zero-emission transportation and renewable energy technologies are key to the future of our urban ecosystems.  Renewable energy platforms can be adjusted in each MINILOOP location, given the renewable energy resources available in each area.  In some applications, a majority of wind turbines may be more efficient, even hydro-electric options if MINILOOP were to travel over water ways.   This gives huge opportunities for reducing the carbon footprint of our cities, as well as greater revenue from MINILOOP's power generated and sold back to the local grid.

 

 

 

MINILOOP does more than just light our streets, it shelters users from the elements and gives opportunity for healthier, active culture in our urban communities.  It gives communities security and peace of mind knowing that the community members are safer than ever from weather conditions, traffic incidents, and other variables of the old transit systems.  It also helps open up the opportunities for communities to build healthy habits and culture around active, healthy lifestyles.  

 

 

MINILOOP systems also provide an opportunity to meet the growing demand for EV charging stations.  With more people turning to electric vehicles, MINILOOP can be the infrastructural backbone for more commuting freedom and range.  By partnering with EV, e-bike, and e-scooter companies, we hope to bring the range and mobility of electric vehicle travel to life in our urban communities.

 

MINILOOP's features allow accessibility and travel by bicycle or scooter to be much easier and more efficient.  Cyclists can utilize the MINILOOP circuits for long distance rides, as well as to get them to parts of the city where they can utilize pre-existing bike routes and recreational spaces such as canyons and mountain biking trails.  With this platform, different districts and sectors of cities can be interconnected and easily traversed like never before on an individual commuter level.  

 

Each location of MINILOOP can be custom tailored to meet the environmental needs of each city, from deserts to tundras, temperate or extreme climate


 

Commuters can take escalators, elevators, and ramps to enter and exit the MINILOOP system.  Bikeshare rentals will be available at MINILOOP stations and sub-stations, as well as e-taxis available within.   

 

In addition to the transportation and renewable energies, MINILOOP also offers for many opportunities for the beautification of the city.  With things like vertical gardens, flowers, and space for artwork each community has the opportunity to further their expression and creativity, with interconnected parks and recreational areas. 
 

 

Funding coming from contributors will go to a number of key goals listed below, and to the completing of milestones in  R A+D's MINILOOP development.  This project is more than just a product or a profit, but it is about creating an entire cultural paradigm shift in how we commute in our urban environments, and lower our carbon footprint doing so. Contributing to MINILOOP is contributing to the evolution of our cities and communities.


FAQ: "Is it worth the investment?"

Answer: Yes! Global statistics and trends show large increases in bicycle users shortly after bike infrastructure development. 
 

Statistics

About 63 percent of citizens in Copenhagen, Netherlands riding their bikes daily, and making up about 48 percent of all city traffic (compared to only 22 percent for vehicles).

"New Orleans saw a 57% increase in cyclists just six months after bike lanes were marked.

Los Angeles also saw a 52% jump in cyclists upon building their new lanes. 

Meanwhile, New York City found it was able to double the number of people commuting by bicycle in just a few years after introducing a few cycling initiatives including bike lanes. "
Care2 Article 

Cities adding bike infrastructure are seeing a “safety in numbers” — more people on bikes plus lower risk of severe or fatal injury.
- NACTO
 

The value of properties within one block of the Indianapolis Cultural Trail increased 148 percent after construction (of marked bike lanes)— more than doubling in value from 2008 to 2015. The $63 million public and private investment helped create $1 billion in additional assessed property value. 
Indiana University Public Policy Institute  


By shifting traffic from cars to bikes and making it easier to reach transit stops, Austin's planned protected bike lane network is projected to increase the city's traffic capacity by about 25,000 trips per day at about the same cost ratio as a single expressway widening. 
Wilkes, Nathan.  - City of Austin 2014 Bike Plan Update." Slide 47. "

 

Our first campaign we are setting a goal of raising $150,000 USD or more  for the spearheading of MINILOOP projects in North America.  If by chance we are unable to meet the $150,000 USD goal, we will be utilizing each penny towards moving our project forward, as well as preparing more campaigns for the project.

 

We are also seeking to partner with private organizations and companies in the construction, bicycle/e-bike/e-scooter, media and advertisement, and plug-in electric automobile manufacturers such as Tesla and Toyota.  Also, we aim to connect with companies such as Hyperloop, Magnovate, airports, and bus lines, to make MINILOOP platforms an auxiliary local transit system connecting to the medium-long distance transit systems.  

 

Who wouldn't like to take a trip across the United States with their bike, using the MINILOOP and other transit systems to get where ever you would like?

 

Funding contributes to:

1.  Development of Construction Documents for submission to various municipalities in North America for permitting 

2. Developments in the MINILOOP 10-20 meter long prototype using construction 3D printing and other cost effective and innovative means in Denver, Colorado 

3. Marketing, branding, and merchandise development for MINILOOP and fulfilling perk rewards

4. Building of photo-realistic, 3D renderings and video tours to be presented to communities, local government and corporations 

 

Contributor’s Perks are put into tiers, but of course any contribution helps to project. 

Tier 1 Donation -$25 
MINILOOP Newsletters and Media Updates, Limited Edition MINILOOP sticker

Tier 2 Donation- $100
MINILOOP Newsletters and Media Updates, Limited Edition MINILOOP sticker, Limited Edition MINILOOP Merchandise, 

Tier 3 Donation- $400
MINILOOP Newsletters and Media Updates, Limited Edition MINILOOP sticker X2, Limited Edition MINILOOP Merchandise X 2, Hard Copy of MINILOOP Booklet. 

 

Some challenges to the MINILOOP project are likely to surface, especially as we present these projects to various City Councils and Mayors around North America for building permits.  We hope to meet these challenges with undeniable community support, optimized project management, and excellent relationships with the cities and their local governments.   Also, by showing the cost-effectiveness of the project using our manufacturing and 3D printing, we hope to evoke greater perception from local government officials.  

 

Thank you so much for taking the time to read our campaign, and we hope that you at least learned something new and broadened your horizons of what is possible in our world and how big of an impact you as an individual can make by contributing to projects such as MINILOOP.

 

Please feel free to share our campaign using the Indiegogo Sharing Tools, and social media on Facebook and Instagram.

 

Facebook: 

R A+D

https://www.facebook.com/Richard-Moreta-Castillo-Foundation-RAD-331873223671548/ 

MINILOOP

https://www.facebook.com/Miniloop-529081344135836/

MINILOOP Inhabitant Article
https://inhabitat.com/this-all-weather-bicycle-highway-could-fulfill-the-dreams-of-bike-commuters-everywhere/

 

Sincerely,

Team R A+D!


For more information, please visit the following sites

Other Recent R A+D Project Publications

Cocoon Smart Home: Off-grid eco-luxury home 

https://inhabitat.com/this-all-weather-bicycle-highway-could-fulfill-the-dreams-of-bike-commuters-everywhere/ 

Exosphere Urban Power Plant, Hotel-Office-Residential Park

https://inhabitat.com/futuristic-power-plant-generates-clean-power-through-wind-solar-and-geothermal-energy/exosphere-architecture/

Mexico's Grand Cancun Eco Platform

https://inhabitat.com/tag/offshore-eco-platform/

Shanghai's Smart Power Long Tower

https://inhabitat.com/shanghai-flying-car-tower-to-clean-the-air-with-a-50000-plant-vertical-forest/

goals listed below, and to the completing of milestones in  R A+D's MINILOOP development.  This project is more than just a product or a profit, but it is about creating an entire cultural paradigm shift in how we commute in our urban environments, and lower our carbon footprint doing so. Contributing to MINILOOP is contributing to the evolution of our cities and communities.FAQ: "Is it worth the investment?"Answer: Yes! Global statistics and trends show large increases in bicycle users shortly after bike infrastructure development.  StatisticsAbout 63 percent of citizens in Copenhagen, Netherlands riding their bikes daily, and making up about 48 percent of all city traffic (compared to only 22 percent for vehicles)."New Orleans saw a 57% increase in cyclists just six months after bike lanes were marked.Los Angeles also saw a 52% jump in cyclists upon building their new lanes. Meanwhile, New York City found it was able to double the number of people commuting by bicycle in just a few years after introducing a few cycling initiatives including bike lanes. "Care2 Article Cities adding bike infrastructure are seeing a “safety in numbers” — more people on bikes plus lower risk of severe or fatal injury.- NACTO The value of properties within one block of the Indianapolis Cultural Trail increased 148 percent after construction (of marked bike lanes)— more than doubling in value from 2008 to 2015. The $63 million public and private investment helped create $1 billion in additional assessed property value. Indiana University Public Policy Institute  By shifting traffic from cars to bikes and making it easier to reach transit stops, Austin's planned protected bike lane network is projected to increase the city's traffic capacity by about 25,000 trips per day at about the same cost ratio as a single expressway widening. Wilkes, Nathan.  - City of Austin 2014 Bike Plan Update." Slide 47. " Our first campaign we are setting a goal of raising $150,000 USD or more  for the spearheading of MINILOOP projects in North America.  If by chance we are unable to meet the $150,000 USD goal, we will be utilizing each penny towards moving our project forward, as well as preparing more campaigns for the project. We are also seeking to partner with private organizations and companies in the construction, bicycle/e-bike/e-scooter, media and advertisement, and plug-in electric automobile manufacturers such as Tesla and Toyota.  Also, we aim to connect with companies such as Hyperloop, Magnovate, airports, and bus lines, to make MINILOOP platforms an auxiliary local transit system connecting to the medium-long distance transit systems.   Who wouldn't like to take a trip across the United States with their bike, using the MINILOOP and other transit systems to get where ever you would like? Funding contributes to:1.  Development of Construction Documents for submission to various municipalities in North America for permitting 2. Developments in the MINILOOP 10-20 meter long prototype using construction 3D printing and other cost effective and innovative means in Denver, Colorado 3. Marketing, branding, and merchandise development for MINILOOP and fulfilling perk rewards4. Building of photo-realistic, 3D renderings and video tours to be presented to communities, local government and corporations  Contributor’s Perks are put into tiers, but of course any contribution helps to project. Tier 1 Donation -$25 MINILOOP Newsletters and Media Updates, Limited Edition MINILOOP stickerTier 2 Donation- $100MINILOOP Newsletters and Media Updates, Limited Edition MINILOOP sticker, Limited Edition MINILOOP Merchandise, Tier 3 Donation- $400MINILOOP Newsletters and Media Updates, Limited Edition MINILOOP sticker X2, Limited Edition MINILOOP Merchandise X 2, Hard Copy of MINILOOP Booklet.  Some challenges to the MINILOOP project are likely to surface, especially as we present these projects to various City Councils and Mayors around North America for building permits.  We hope to meet these challenges with undeniable community support, optimized project management, and excellent relationships with the cities and their local governments.   Also, by showing the cost-effectiveness of the project using our manufacturing and 3D printing, we hope to evoke greater perception from local government officials.   Thank you so much for taking the time to read our campaign, and we hope that you at least learned something new and broadened your horizons of what is possible in our world and how big of an impact you as an individual can make by contributing to projects such as MINILOOP. Please feel free to share our campaign using the Indiegogo Sharing Tools, and social media on Facebook and Instagram. Facebook: R A+Dhttps://www.facebook.com/Richard-Moreta-Castillo-Foundation-RAD-331873223671548/ MINILOOPhttps://www.facebook.com/Miniloop-529081344135836/MINILOOP Inhabitant Articlehttps://inhabitat.com/this-all-weather-bicycle-highway-could-fulfill-the-dreams-of-bike-commuters-everywhere/ Sincerely,Team R A+D!For more information, please visit the following sitesOther Recent R A+D Project PublicationsCocoon Smart Home: Off-grid eco-luxury home https://inhabitat.com/this-all-weather-bicycle-highway-could-fulfill-the-dreams-of-bike-commuters-everywhere/ Exosphere Urban Power Plant, Hotel-Office-Residential Parkhttps://inhabitat.com/futuristic-power-plant-generates-clean-power-through-wind-solar-and-geothermal-energy/exosphere-architecture/Mexico's Grand Cancun Eco Platformhttps://inhabitat.com/tag/offshore-eco-platform/Shanghai's Smart Power Long Towerhttps://inhabitat.com/shanghai-flying-car-tower-to-clean-the-air-with-a-50000-plant-vertical-forest/

story:
Qlio Velo is a Human Powered Pedal Assist Velomobile (quadricycle).

Built on an aluminium frame, fully enclosed with impact protective foam, it combines the benefits of the bicycle, car and public transport in one state-of-the-art product.

Suitable for riding year-round no matter the weather and road conditions, Qlio will take you forward and farther.

You can ride it around the block or around the world with the aid of the built-in Pedal Powered AC Generator.

Classified as a Pedelec (worldwide*) it is road legal and can be driven without a license.

The DC brushless electric motor can give from 250W to over 1000W* of max power, with a max speed of 45Km/h* and can be operated through e-drive, assisted pedaling or by pedaling alone. (*according to each country regulations: 250W, 500W, 750W, 1000W)  

NO pollution! It's common sense. Pedal power Maximized for Unlimited Range.

 

High-impact Resistant Foam Panels offer all-around protection (inside & out), all-year, all-weather and all-terrain. 

Its fully enclosed modular structure comes with front and back crash crumple zones, side impact protection, hydraulic brakes and 2 seat belts.

We have designed it to have a modular outer shell, that can be transformed to better serve the users personal needs and/or commercial activities.

Modular assembly makes it easy to change or repair and is 100% recyclable.

Simplexity: Practically Beautiful

At Qlio Velo we have designed a completely new velomobile to overcome all shortcomings associated with this type of personal transportation.

Beauty is a need; it's something we crave and gravitate toward.  Qlio Velo meets both Beauty and Functionality.

Optimized for visibility, it comes equipped with headlights, fog lights, rear lights, brake lights and indicator lights.

Steering and control over vehicle functions is made via a centered handlebar which makes it very easy to operate.

It features simple electric and mechanical gears also offering a reverse function.

The Qlio Velo's minimalist appearance was inspired by 1920's design principles of creating more with less.

We focused on both rural and urban mobility creating a paradigm shift in the way people imagine velomobiles.

Using scientific methodology we have created a vehicle with a true global value, environmentally friendly, safe, beautiful and practical.

 

  • protective foam interior
  • 360° woven fiber and resin reinforced impact resistant foam shell
  • 2 x seat belts
  • rigid aluminium latter chassis
  • 4 wheel hydraulic disk brakes
  • hand brake (for uphill-downhill parking)
  • waterproof and *fireproof (* frame and body)
  • fully enclosed
  • 1 x windshield wiper
  • alarm system
  • remote control motor locking

​

  • lounge mode / carry mode
  • portable Bluetooth Radio/Speaker ( retro style design)
  • 4 front USB charging ports 
  • 2 back seat USB charging ports
  • portable LED lamp
  • ​driver & passenger reading lamps
  • ​remote controlled LED ambient lights
  • 20.000 mAh power bank
  • removable Air Cooler / Heater
  • parking rear view camera
  • adjustable front seat

  • pedal assist hub motor
  • pedal assist top speed: 25km/h | 15.5mph
  • optimal top speed: 45km/h | 28mph
  • thumb throttle assist: 6km/h | 3.7mph
  • power options: 250W, 500W, 750W, 1000W
  • rear-wheel drive system (RWD)
  • 12 V - 1000 W pedal powered generator
  • Panasonic battery pack: 7 x 12V 20Ah
  • 4 wheels independent suspension
  • LED : headlights, fog lights, brake lights and indicator lights
  • side door - warning lights
  • ​welcome lights 
  • modular body
  • 100% recyclable
  • 50 years warranty (rustproof frame and body)

 

First I would like to extend my sincere gratitude to all collaborators from around the world: ISRAEL, US, UK, CHINA, JAPAN, INDIA, GERMANY, ROMANIA and MYANMAR.

I myself am a visual artist, a painter and a designer with an interest towards functionality.

As a background my father is a master mechanic and electrician, my mother a medic, my grandfather a carpenter and my grandmother a tailor.

Since childhood I have reconstructed cars and built many electric vehicles, small cars, boats and airplanes, but nothing for production purposes.   

Qlio Velo is the first Safe & Comfortable Pedal Assisted - Self Charging Velomobile in the world.

The idea came because there is nothing of this kind in the world, to recharge on the go. 

I wanted something simple yet comfortable, safe and environmentally friendly. More than that, to be able to fix or replace the components anywhere in the world with very little knowledge of mechanics or electrical engineering. Almost all of the components are off-the-shelf products.

This project started 7 years ago and although I already had some mechanical and electrical knowledge, I went back to school to expand my vision.  

At the beginning I wanted to built only one model for myself, but the more I talked about it, my friends and family pushed me into creating a production model.

Velomobile, why not?

Most of the velomobiles on the market are for hobbyists and are mainly man oriented. 

I wanted something that everyone can enjoy, big or small, young and old.

It is built this way so that even my mother, sister or girlfriend to ride in safety and comfort. For many years I have tried to promote different pedal powered vehicles to my mother, but she always pointed out the lack of safety. Qlio Velo is dedicated to both parents and children around the world. 

It might not be the world's fastest velomobile but it is the safest.

Qlio Velo is manufactured using all existing parts to keep production costs low, while ensuring quality. The rustproof frame is made of aluminium and the body is made of fireproof foam with a lifespan of 50 years.

The future is Self Powered

Our mission is to build affordable, efficient and environmentally sustainable self powered electric vehicles, because only a light vehicle can be operated in an energy-saving manner.

Qlio Velo is the embodiment of both old and new ways, rearranged to fit our present need for a sustainable healthy life.

Development plans

We hope to preserve the beauty and minimalism of the 1920's vehicle style and open new assembly lines in US (California), EU (Germany, Romania) and ASIA (Myanmar). 

How can you  help?

Your donations to our campaign will help us to hire new personnel and acquire specialized manufacturing equipment to streamline the production process.

We follow a human centered business model (P2P).

All Qlio models are hand crafted in a safe and controlled manufacturing process. 

We're excited to implement our first assembly line and aim to fulfill on time to each and every backer.      

A few seconds of your time could make the difference. Hit one of the buttons below and help Qlio Velo grow.  We can't do this without you.​

Let's do something amazing.  

 

 

What people say about Qlio Velo

We are happy to get almost 100% positive reviews and thank all people that took the time to review our project.

story:
The Fifth Mode of Transportation is HERE!

On June 15, 2015, SpaceX announced their intention to host a competition and build a test tube at their headquarters in Hawthorne, CA. As of January 31, 2016, the University of Wisconsin-Madison was awarded the 3rd best overall design by Judges at Design Weekend in Texas. We will be joined by 30 other international teams building pods for the test track in Hawthorne, CA. Competing in this talented arena will be a challenge, but we are confident in our ability to succeed.

Check out our virtual reality concept demonstration!

Pictured above: BadgerLoop at Texas A&M during Design Weekend. 

The existence of the UW-Madison Hyperloop Pod Competition Team, BadgerLoop, relies on the strong support of individuals like you! This support offers innovative engineering students the opportunity to collaborate on this challenging project gaining valuable design and fabrication experience. Taking this concept from idea to reality is no small feat, and we hope that you will consider sponsoring the BadgerLoop Team by contributing consultation services, monetary gifts, equipment/materials, or anything you feel would be beneficial to our endeavor.

Pictured above: Cross section of our pod design.

To gain a competitive edge, we are going above and beyond the competition requirements by incorporating innovative designs such as regenerative power axles, redundant brakes, industry-grade control systems, magnetic propulsion, virtual reality, and much more.

As seen on:

Popular Science, The Verge, University of Wisconsin News, NBC, Geek Wire

story:
What we're about:

The aim of this campaign is to provide high quality, safe, stylish and most of all, fun eBikes at an affordable price. We're proud of the FatMini and can't wait to share it with you.

We've been producing small batches so far, but we know we can do more. With the support of our backers we will be able to produce larger quantities, and maintain the new low price.

Goals:

Our goal amount is flexible, if we don't quite make it that's OK, likewise if we exceed the goal amount we can still meet the delivery target. The more FatMini we can release into the wild, the better!

Thanks for your support everyone - even if you cant back us at the moment, we'd really appreciate it if you could hit those share buttons :-)

Ben - FatMini eBikes

 

 

In a nutshell:

The FatMini is the only folding fat eBike in the UK. Equipped with a UK road legal 250w Bafang motor, high quality Samsung battery pack, and most importantly -  Fat 4" Kenda tyres!

The FatMini combines the best of both an electric fatbike and a folding bike. It's super comfy due to it's suspended seatpost, front fork Mozo Suspension, and also the fat tyres themselves. When folded it can easily be transported it in your car, or it can help to save a bit of space wherever it's stored.

Only high quality, brand name components are used in the construction of the FatMini

 

HOW DOES IT WORK?

The FatMini, like all UK eBikes utilises a Pedal Assist (known as PAS). This means that as you pedal, the bike will assist you to varying degrees. There are 5 levels of assistance available. At level 1, the motor will take the edge off your effort, at level 5, you're putting in almost no effort at all, and the motor is doing the work for you. Handy if you live at the top of a hill!

WHAT SORT OF RANGE CAN I EXPECT?

The range is effected by a number of factors, such as terrain and PAS level used. The FatMini will return between 15-35 miles per charge.

 

HOW LONG DOES IT TAKE TO CHARGE?

About 4 hours.

HOW MUCH DOES FATMINI WEIGH?

27KG

WILL FATMINI FIT ME?

Almost certainly, the seatpost and handlebar stem have a large range of adjustment:

58cm reach, 61cm Stand Over Height, 170cm Length

Max rider weight is 100kg

SHIPPING

FatMini ships (at no additional cost!) from North Wales, to anywhere in the UK.

DETAILED SPEC

SUSPENSION

Mozo front fork suspension

BRAKE DETAILS:

Tektro Novela Mechanical Disc with 180 mm Front Rotor and 160 mm Rear Rotor, Tektro Levers with Motor Inhibitors

MOTOR BRAND:

Bafang

MOTOR POWER:

205W

MOTOR TORQUE:

50 Newton meters

ESTIMATED MAX RANGE:

35 miles (56 km)

BATTERY BRAND:

10.4 Ah Samsung Li-ion Battery (with integrated lock and spare keys)

CHARGE TIME:

4 hours

GRIPS:

Brown Ergonomic, Stitched (matches saddle)

SADDLE:

Velo VL-8020E, Comfort

SEAT POST:

Promax SP-252, Aluminum Alloy with Suspension

GEARING DETAILS:

Shimano 7 speed

SHIFTER DETAILS:

Shimano Tourney TX50R6CT Thumb Shifter Plus

CRANKS:

Alloy Bash Guard, 52T Chainring

PEDALS:

Folding Platform

ACCESSORIES:

Integrated Spanninga Trendo LED headlamp, independent rear light, Flick Bell, Steel Fenders, Carry Rack with Spring Latch (25 kg Max Load)

READOUTS:

Battery Gauge (5 Bars), Assist Level (1-5), Speed, Avg. Speed, Top Speed, Odometer, Trip Odometer

STEM:

Telescoping

HANDLEBAR:

Promax Flat, 23" Length

DRIVE MODE:

Cadence Sensing Pedal Assist





 

TOTAL WEIGHT:

26.98 kg

BATTERY WEIGHT:

3.49 kg

MOTOR WEIGHT:

5.44 kg

FRAME MATERIAL:

6061 Aluminum

FRAME TYPE:

Step-Through, Folding

FRAME COLOUR:

Matt Black

FRAME FORK DETAILS:

Rigid, 11 mm Axle

FRAME REAR DETAILS:

11 mm Axle

ATTACHMENT POINTS:

Rear Rack Bosses, Fender Bosses

 

SEAT POST LENGTH:

350 mm

SEAT POST DIAMETER:

27.2 mm

RIMS:

Double Walled Alloy, Black

SPOKES:

13 Gauge, Stainless Steel

TYRE BRAND:

Kenda Krusade, 20" x 4"

WHEEL SIZES:

20 in (50.8cm)

TIRE DETAILS:

5-30 PSI

TUBE DETAILS:

Schrader Valve

 

OTHER:

Locking Removable Battery Pack, Rust Resistant KMC chain,Prowheel Chain ring,Heavy Duty Kickstand

story:
The Problem

Do you or someone you know ever haul your bikes in your pickup truck? How do you load your bikes? How do you secure the bikes? How many bikes can you haul? How about other gear - do you have to unload other stuff to load the bikes?  

Does your rack have to be removed when not in use? Do your bikes have to ride on a rack behind the vehicle in the spray and dust and grit off the road?


When the bikes are loaded is there any room left to load your camping gear?

Do your bikes bounce around and get tangled and beat each other up and scratch the truck?

Do you have to unload all the bikes to open the tailgate for loading other gear?

How much time does it take to load and unload?

Hauling bikes in your pickup truck poses lots of problems.


The Solution

The KURUK Bike Rack for Pickup Trucks solves all of the problems associated with loading bikes and gear in a pickup.

The KURUK wheel holder instantly adjusts to any bike tire size and clamps it in like a Chinese handcuff. Even if the tire goes flat the KURUK rack synchs up tight.

A fully loaded truck bed is NO PROBLEM for the KURUK rack. Bikes are loaded on top of the load and you can still pull a trailer.

The bikes are up out of the road spray and dust. You still have full access to open the tailgate.

Up to 6 bike capacity on a standard size truck and you can still close the tailgate of a short bed truck even with big bikes.

The KURUK rack loves FAT or SKINNY tires.


OUR Story

•  My name is Dan Wolfe. I have always been an avid biker. I love to spend as much time as possible on the mountain trails with my biking buddies and when the trails are snowed in we load our camping gear and travel to other locations where the trails are still open or we ride the roads as well. 

•  We also are truck lovers and we haul our bikes and all our gear in our pickup trucks. Over the years we have bought about every variation of truck bed bike rack on the market, but all of them had numerous problems that we didn't like to deal with. The wheel removal and clamping and strapping, etc. etc. were robbing us of precious biking time and causing many other aggravations like shifting bikes, damage to the truck or the bikes or both. Almost all of the other racks we tried obstructed cargo space and had to be removed when not hauling bikes then reinstalled next time. We didn't like having our expensive bikes back in the dust and grit and spray off the road from the trucks wheels. The bikes themselves were in  the way of loading our camping and other gear. 

• So we invented a rack that did away with all of these problems. It became very popular and in demand in our local area. But it was built for only 26 inch mountain bikes and many people wanted a rack that would fit their 29ers or road bikes. Now FAT bikes are cool, but the original "FastRack" just didn't work for all of these popular sizes so we reinvented the FastRack. 

•  We have now solved ALL of these problems with the new KURUK Bike Rack. It clamps in place up on the truck bed side walls just behind the pickup's back window. 

• It doesn't obstruct bed space so it never needs to be removed in order to load other gear in the bed. Bikes can be loaded instantly whether other cargo is in the bed or not. Up to 6 bikes will ride securely on top of the load. No wheel removal, or clamping, or strapping, or shifting bikes. More bikes can be loaded in less space. The KURUK rack accepts ALL sizes of bikes and instantly adjusts to various wheel sizes and grips them like a Chinese hand cuff. If the tire goes flat it still holds tight.

• 2 million bikers in the US haul their bikes in their trucks. We have done the research and proven that the KURUK rack has large market appeal, but the tooling up and manufacturing of the KURUK Rack is an expensive project. We are just regular guys with regular jobs and don't have the cash to make it happen without your help.

Pickup trucks are meant to haul things yet hauling our bikes in our truck beds has been a pain in the ***!  

UNTIL  >>>>  KURUK

KURUK Advantages

• KURUK racks and bikes never obstruct cargo space

•  Racks don't have to be installed and removed between rides

•  KURUK racks facilitate instant loading and unloading

• They instantly adjust to ALL bike wheel sizes

• They prevent damage to bikes and trucks

• Never require removal of wheels or strapping or clamping 

• Bikes are SECURE on rough roads

• Built durable with 2 year warranty

• Bikes are up out of the road spray and dirt from vehicle tires

• Short bed trucks are no problem for big bikes with tailgate closed

• KURUK racks hold more bikes in less space (up to 6 in standard truck)

• KURUK racks adjusts and mount to various pickup or trailer sizes


The Cost

•  We need to raise $75,000 to get the first racks ready for market. Aluminum extrusion molds cost over $40,000. Then materials and tooling cost another $25,000. Another $10,000 will be used for marketing and to set up packaging and order fulfillment. KURUK racks will be made here in America to create more jobs at home. 

•  With your help we can make it happen. Your contribution of $150 to $420 will get you a KURUK Rack as soon as the first units are produced. Clubs and shops can pre-order multiple units. (We expect to ship first orders in the spring of 2016). This is about 1/2 the regular retail price. 

• Smaller contributions will score some great swag and will be greatly appreciated.

• Even if you can't contribute - your referrals to your friends would be very much appreciated. Please share this with your friends on social media.

The Impact

•  When we started building our own racks for our own use in our garages they were pretty crude, but they worked well and we kept improving on them. Then other bikers started noticing them and asking us if we could make one for their trucks as well. Before long they became very popular in the local biking community then we got a website and started getting orders from all over the country. We continued to make major improvements and then applied for and got a patent. Now we are ready to make it a real business and start serving the general biking population. We are determined to keep it American and create some great jobs here at home. You can be a part of this effort with a contribution as small or large as you wish. Together - let's create the most innovative and versatile pickup truck  bike rack ever invented. The KURUK Bike Rack.


Risks & Challenges

 •  KURUK is a unique product with several new innovations, however, we have built and thoroughly tested many prototypes and have proven the product.  To mitigate risks, we are working with experienced partners in innovation, manufacturing, and marketing. Our aluminum castings partner has many years of experience and hundreds of great successes.

• Our only real obstacle is getting the word out. We are going after a small niche market, but with 50 million pickup owners in the US and over 200 million bike riders we are pretty sure that the overlap is significant.

 • Our main priority is to ensure the overall product quality and that we deliver an exceptional product that will perform better for longer then our customers expect. We will not cut corners to save money. We intend to blow our customers away with more service for the money than expected.

• We have all the pieces in place. Your contribution will be very carefully and conservatively used to create a great new product and small business.

Our most important motivation is You and your support. You make the creation of KURUK possible. So thank you!

• Be ASSURED that you WILL get your KURUK rack even if we don't reach our full goal. We have financial partners standing by. We hope not to need their money so we can keep full control of the business.


Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

•  Whether or not you are able to contribute - you can help to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Please invite everyone in all of your social media platforms to watch our video and pass it on.

•  Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools and share this on facebook, twitter, Linkedin, email, pintrist, and every other social platform that you use!

Reaching OUT

One more very important thing: A good friend of ours and an avid biker (Jeff Page from West Jordan, Utah) was recently involved in a devastating biking accident and broke his neck. He is fighting back, but it's a long tough road and  his medical bills are mounting. Will you please go to his website and contribute anything you can? https://www.gofundme.com/7s2p4cpk

We thank you sincerely and deeply for your help.


SUPPORTERS
